Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Twenty-three years of tidal marsh response to environmental change
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary scientific objective of this project is to unravel how elevated atmospheric carbon dioxide, nitrogen pollution, climate change, sea-level rise and plant invasion interact to control the sustainability of tidal marsh ecosystems. The wealth of long-term global change research at the study site affords an unprecedented comparison of the relative importance of these factors. This twenty-three year record of global change has shown that effects that appear important in the short term may be obviated or reversed when longer-term trends are considered. The central hypothesis is that changes in plant community composition will mediate the most important effects of global change on ecosystem sustainability. To address this, the researchers will extend the record of ongoing global change treatments, continue monitoring ecosystem response and initiate new experimentation with plant communities.

The information garnered from the proposed research will inform management practices aimed at protecting and restoring coastal wetlands. Tidal wetlands make up the ecological fabric of coastal and estuarine ecosystems providing ecosystem services such as nourishing food chains, filtering water and protecting coastal populations. The most important ecosystem endpoint is soil elevation gain, because tidal marshes must gain soil to keep up with sea-level rise. Otherwise, the marsh will be converted to open water and the critical ecosystem services will be irreversibly lost. This interdisciplinary project will train researchers at all levels and inform the public about the critical issues of sea level rise and elevated carbon dioxide. Six undergraduate students will be involved in the project, and the study site hosts thousands of elementary and high school aged students through intensive science camps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project is to unravel how long-term trends in elevated CO2, N pollution, climate, sea level rise and plant invasion interact to regulate carbon assimilation by plants and carbon mineralization by microbes in this ecosystem. The balance of these two processes--carbon gain and carbon loss-- ultimately determines the capacity of the wetland to increase elevation at a rate that matches sea level rise, and persist in a rapidly changing environment. Our central hypothesis is that current and expected trends in elevated CO2, N loading and sea level will act through both plant productivity and plant community composition to regulate soil surface elevation.

 Our specific objectives during the past year of funding were: (i) to continue applying treatments to three tidal wetland global change experiments, (ii) complete two new, one-year sea level experiments in the marsh organ facility, (iii) initiate a second new set of long-term tidal export chemistry observations in a tidal creek flume the marsh complex, (iv) publish results, and (v) make substantial progress archiving data. We largely met these goals.

 We successfully completed year 29 of an elevated carbon dioxide treatment during the growing season of our long-term experiment; year 10 of a second experiment that crosses elevated CO2 and nitrogen pollution; and year 5 of an experiment on the influence of elevated CO2 and N on Phragmites australis invasion. There was progress on several fronts, the highlights of which we provide here.

 A Smithsonian-funded post-doctoral fellow, Dr. Blanca Bernal, completed a novel quantification of soil carbon turnover times using the unique carbon isotopic signature of plants growing in elevated CO2 at our site. This was possible by doing a retrospective analysis of carbon isotopic signatures on archived plant material, and new samples of soil organic matter. This work is novel because it directly measures the rate of soil organic matter cycling in a systems where turnover times are low and very hard to estimate.

 A major accomplishment was the public posting of nearly all the long-term data generated by nearly 30 years of research on four experiments at this LTREB-funded site. They are posted on a website (www.serc.si.edu/gcrew) that provides context to the site, questions, experiments and the data itself. We anticipate posting more data in 2016.

We completed one year of high-resolution (15 minute) water chemistry and flux observations at the GCREW flume, combined with monthly 24-hour grab samples for a range of additional chemistry analyses. Continuously measured analytes include O2, pH, fDOM, chlorophyll, suspended sediment. These data are supporting the integration of marsh export dynamics into a hydrologic model of the Rhode River, where the marsh is located.

A marsh-wide campaign to map plant communities, establish permanent plots, and quantify plant cover and biomass was completed. This effort will be the basis of regular monitoring of marsh-wide plant cover, in addition to the biomass measurements produced each year from our experiments.
